bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, May 10, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 68. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, MAY 10, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.

p.add: See his No. 63, of Feb'y 19, 1901 Acknowledged June 15, 1901.

div1.p: Subject. Transmitted of copies of all correspondence, in relation to the estate of the late William Parker; between the Administrator James (George) H. Lewis; the State Department, Monrovia, and this Consulate General..
No. 68. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia; May 10, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to transmit, herewith, copies of all correspondence, relative to the estate of the late William Parker, between James (George by mistake on my part) H. Lewis, the Administrator of the esstate; the State Department, Monrovia, and this Consulate General.
By a close reading of my letter to James H. Lewis, the Administrator, in whose house Parker, resided and diedl you will observe that

that I set up the claim that Parker was and died an American citizen. You will further observe, that James H. Lewis, the Administrator, in none of his replies, as Administrator; denies my claim that Parker was an American citizen; but tacitly admits my claim by promising to forward the effects of the deceased to this Consulate General.

In my No 4/1901, Miscellaneous, January 29, 1901, to the State Department, Monrovia; complaining of the silency and non action of the Administrator; the State Department, in reply informed me that the Attorney General, had been instructed to correspond with the said James H. Lewis, the
the Administrator; advising him to comply with the terms of the law &c.

In reply to the Attorney General's letter; upon inquiry, at the Executive Mansion, the President informed me that James H. lewis, the Administrator had answered the Attorney General; informing him that he, James H. Lewis, had sold the effects of the deceased, and would soon come down and make a report to the Attorney General, which he James H. Lewis, the Administrator, thought, would be satisfacotry to the Attorney General. Having reeived such information from the President, I demurred, at the expressed desire to make his report to the Attorney General, and filed my Protest,

Protest No. 10/1901, Miscellaneous, March 16, 1901, to the State Department, Monrovia. To this Protest, the Liberian Government, to date, has failed to make a direct reply, to this Consulate General. It has, however, indirectly, replied, by instructing the Hon. R. J. B. Watson, the Superintendent of Grand Cape Mount Territory, to cause the said James H. Lewis,, the Administrator, to make an immediate report, transmitting the proceeds &c of said estate, direct to me.
Upon the receipt of the report of James H. Lewis, the Administrator, I was confined to my bed, very sick; but without opening the report; I directed the Secretary of the Legation to

to take the sealed packages to the Attorney General of the Liberian Government, open the said packages, read te report and varify the statements, accounts &c, and bring the same back to this Consulate General.

After reading the report, finding them short in many respects I wrote my No. 13/1901. Miscellaneous, April 16, 1901, to which I have received us reply, direct nor indirectly, from the Liberian Government.
Awaiting your instructions, I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith, C. General.
Copy
No. 4/1901. Miscellaneous Legation of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, Jan. 29, 1901.
Hon. W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State, Monrovia

Sir: I have the honor to call your attention to the fact that Mn Parker late of Spokane, state of Washington, United States of America emigrated from the United States to Liberia during the summer of 1900, reaching here in September 1900. He left his wife and family in America. He left this city in the latter part of september for Cape Mount Liberia, during the same month. He stopped while in Cape Mount with one James H. Lewis. It appears that the Judge of the monthly and Probate Court of

of said Territory being the uncle of said James H. Lewis, the sheriff appointed him the administrator of the estate and effects of the deceased Wm Parker, with authority to collect and settle the estate of the deceased Wm Parker.

The intelligence of the death of Wm Parker reached this Legation during the latter part of Nov. 1900. Whereupon I at once communicated with the said James H. Lewis the administrator forbidding him to sell the effects of the deceased, but directing him to collect same box them up and transmit them to me at Monrovia, accompanied with an inventory and statement of three respectable persons as apprasiers, with statement of expenses &c for settlement by the American Consul Generals to Liberia.

The said James H. Lewis has since written to me asking permission to sell the eeffects and make settlements &c as may suite himself. He also asked how he should forward the residence of the said estate to me. In reply I informed him that I had no authority of law by which I could authorize him to sell said effects and directed him to forward same to me by Messrs. Houston Brother's vessel. Having made proper arrangements with Messrs. Houston Brothers for the transportation of said effects, and delivered the letter to Messrs Houston Brothers to be delivered to Mr. Lewis upon the arrival of said vessel at Robertsport with the advice to deliver said effects to the captain of said vessel. Upon the return of said vessel Messrs

Messrs. Houston Brothers informed me that they forwarded the letter even before the sailing of the vessel in order that Mr. Lewis might have everything ready for shipment upon the animal of the vessel but upon animal Mr. Lewis failed to deliver the effects &c.
Now I write to ask that the said James H. Lewis Esq., be directed that he forward the said effects without further delay to me or show just cause for his actions in said matter.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith M. R. and Consul General
Copy
Department of State, Monrovia, Liberia January 31st 1901.

Sir, Refering to your communication of the 29th inst. I have the honor to inform you that the subject matter contained therein, has been refered to the Attorney General, who has been directed to order the Probate Court of Grand Cape Mount Territory to forward the effect of Mr. William Parker deceased to your Legation immediately. All expense incured as stated in your communication to be borne by yourself.
Trusting that the matter may have a
a speedy termination.
I have the honor to be, Sir, your obedient servant, W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State Hon. O. L. W. Smith U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General U.S. Legation Monrovia
Copy
No. 10/1901. Miscellaneous Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, March 16, 1901.
Hon. W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State, Monrovia

Sir: I have the honor to say, that this Consulate General, having been informed during the latter part of November, 1900, of the very sudden death of the late William Parker an American citizen, late of the city of Spokane, State of Washington, United States of America, the said William Parker having come to Liberia, during the month of September, 1900, prospecting with a view to locating here and becoming a Liberian citizen in case he found surroundings favorable, the wife and other

other heirs at law of the said William Parker having been left in the city of Minneapolis State of Minnesota, United States of America, awaiting the full determination of the said William Parker, as to whether he would renounce his allegiance to the Government of the United States and swer allegiance to other Government, the said William Parker however brought many effects &c. with him such as a man of a prosper disposition would have desc to have with him in case of a final determination to settle in this country, died Nov. 14, 1900, in the residence and home of one James H. Lewis a Liberian citien of Robertsport, Territory of Grand Cape Mount Republic of Liberia. This Consulate General was further

informed that the judge of the montly and Probate Court of said Grand Cape Mount Territory, being the uncle of the said James H. Lewis, appointed him the said James H. Lewis the administrator of the effects &c. of the late William Parker deceased with authority to sell the effects of the deceased, settle his his estate and transmit the residnce of the effects to the widow of the deceased William Parker in America instead of communicating the facts of his death, and the forwarding the effects of the deceased to this Consulate General in whose Consular District the said William Parker died Steaming of the Proceedings of the Monthly and Probate Court of said Territory in said case, I at once in accordance

accordance with the stipulated duties of an American Consul in a Christian Country as will appear on page 154, paragraph 385 First United States Consular Regulations, 1896 communicated with the said James H. Lewis informing him that he could not sell the effects of the deceased nor transmit the proceeds thereof to the widow of the deceased in the United States but that he should send said effects with a duplicate copy of an inventory of the said effects of the deceased with a bill of all necessary expenses &c to this Consulate General for settlement and transmission to the United States.
In reply the said James H. Lewis wrote me that he desired to sell sufficient of the said effects

effects of the deceased to settle such claims as he held against the deceased. I again wrote him citing the provisions of the law, page 161 paragraph 409, Consular Regulation of said effects to this Consulate General and again so notified said James H. Lewis.

Receiving no reply from him, I laid the matter before the State Department Monrovia for immediate action in the case as I had not been and am not yet placed in a position to make a proper report to my Government owing to the arbitrary and dictory of the said James H. Lewis.
Now since your Government through the Department of Justice has communicated with

with the Judge of the Montly and Probate Court of said Territory on with James H. Lewis relative to said effects and demanding the said effects be forwarded to this Consulate General, I am further informed that the said James H. Lewis some days after the receipt of the order from the Attorney General did expose and sell the said effects of the deceased William Parker and has written the Attorney General that he (James H. Lewis at his own convenience) would come down adn make a report to the Attorney General who knows nothing of the effects of the deceased William Parker the which he (james H. Lewis) thinks will be satisfactory to the Attorney General.

The said James H. Lewis in accepting the responsibility of becoming the administrator of the estate of the deceased American citizen, dying in this Consular District thus becomes a quasisubordinate Consular Officer of the United States in this case is amenable to this Consulate General for his administration of the affairs of the estate of a deceased American citizen and the full and faithful accomability thereof to this Consulate General. Therefore as Consul General of the United States to Liberia under whose supervision the effects of deceased American citizens dying within the limits of this Consular District some I claim that James H. Lewis has

has no authority under the country of international law to make such an indicated desired report upon such a matter affecting the honest intentions of two soverign nations the Attorny General on to the State Department suparate and apart from the representative of the other power who holds a list and has a knowledge of much of the personal effects of the deceased American citizen, as many articles of the effects of the deceased were on deposit in the Consulate General up to the day of the departure of of the deceased firm this city for Robertsport. For the foregoing such indicated desired exparte proceedings on the part of said James H. Lewis.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant Owen L. W. Smith Consul Gen.
Copy
No. 19/1901. Miscellaneous. Legation of the United States. Monrovia, Liberia April 16, 1901.
Hom. W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State, Monrovia

Sir: I have the honor to say, that in relation to the effects of the late William Parker deceased, that the very incomplete report of James H. Lewis Esq., the administrator of the said effects and the Sheriff of Grand Cape Mount Territory is by no means satisfactory to this Consulate General nore to the Government of the United States. To particularize, First, the administrator charges the estate with two dollars for the services of two appraisers for dollars and seventy-five cents, to

to clerk of Court for according the inventory; yet he utterly fails to give this Consulate General any report of the work of the appraisers or a duplicate certified copy of the Inventory. I therefore ask that the said James H. Lewis be demanded to furnish this Consulate General direct or through the Department of State with a certified copy of the original findings and estimates of the aforesaid appraisers for which the estate of the aforesaid William Parker is charged, or the original Inventory as reported to the Court in duplicate, certified by the clerk of said court, as being a true and faithful copy of the said original inventory.
Second. The said James H. Lewis, in his capacity as

administrator of the estate of the late William Parker, did expose for sale and did sell all the valuable effects of the deceased William Parker, as per his report as administrator amounting to Ninety-Seven 40/100 dollars ($97.40) yet he failed to accompany his report with a copy of the Bill of Sales, giving an itemized account, stating for what amount each article of said estate sold. The missing itemized Bill of Sales; showing what articles in the list of Inventory he sold, the prices obtained for each article & c. I do most respectfully ask that you demand of the said James H. Lewis and that the same be furnished this Consulate General.
Third. The said James H. Lewis in his report as administrator changes the estate of the deceased William Parker for accounts claimed

claimed to have been paid by the said administrator, against the estate of the deceased and for his services rendered including 5 percent commission, the sum of Fifty-six 13/100 dollars and yet he fails to substantiate a single item claimed to have been paid by him by the presentation of any accompanying receipt or voucher given by the party or parties receiving said amounts. I therefore ask that the said James H. Lewis be damanded to furnish said receipts or vouchers or refund the entire amount paid by him less his command $16.25.
Fourth. Knowing as I do the very miserly manner in which the deceased William Parker before he went to Robertsport brought to this Consulate General for

for safe keeping. Two hundred and twenty dollars in unconvertable American Express Company's Certificates of Credit wrapped and closely bound together with, in the same package Â£30 sterling and two American Ten dollars gold pieces, making a totla of One Hundred and Sixty-four dollars in coins besides the Two Hundred and Twenty dollars in Certificates of Credit: and that on the Morning of September 27, 1900; the day that the deceased left the city for Robertsport, he called at this Consulate General, called for and received the said money and money credits or certificates and did most carefully wrap and find the money and money credits together even before leaving this Consulate General, making it almost

almost next to impossible for my one to have obtained money credits or certificates without having obtained the Â£30 sterling and the two American Ten Dollar gold pieces. And whereas the said James H. Lewis in all of his correspondence with me relative to the estate of the deceased has observed entire reticency touching the One Hundred and sixty-four dollars in com and even in his report to me as administrator of the effects of the deceased notwithstanding he forwarded to me Two Hundred and Twenty dollars in incomentable Certificates of Credit yet he says not a word relative to the Â£30 sterling, and the two American Ten Dollar pieces or the One Hundred and Sixty-four

dollars in coin. I therefore claim that the acknowledged possession and presentation of the Two Hundred and Twenty DOllars in unconventable certificates by the said administrator. James H. Lewis, aforesaid is prima facie evidence that he is or has been in possession of the Â£30 Sterling and the Two American Ten Dollar gold pieces. Again his entire reticency relative to the Â£30 sterling and the Two American Ten dollar gold pieces referred to in my first letter to the said James H. Lewis relative to the effects of the deceased William Parker and making no mention of in his report as administrator is presumptive evidence that he is or has been in possession

of the Â£30 Sterling and the two American Ten Dollar gold pieces. I therefore ask that the said James H. Lewis be suspended from all offices of trust and profit, and that his bondsmen as administrator of the estate of the late William Parker be attached for the default of the said administrator in the full and faitful discharge of the duties of said office, and that the said James H. Lewis be apprehended and confined in the common jail or jails of this Republic until full restitution for the said Â£30 sterling and the two American ten dollars gold pieces is made.
Awaiting your reply, I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith. Consul General.
Miscellaneous Legation of the United States Monrovia, Liberia, Nov. 26, 1900.
James H. Lewis, Esq., Robertsport (Cape Mount) Liberia.

Sir: I have the honor to say that I am just apprised of the death Nov. 13, 1900, of William Parker, late of Spokane, state of Washington U.S.A. I am further informed by His Honor Judge H. W. Travis, that you have been appointed the administrator of the effects &c of Mr. Parker, and have been advised to take an inventory of the effects &c., collect all debts &c. due the deceased, pay all debts due by the deceased sell the

the residence of said effects &c. and send the proceeds thereof to the widow of the deceased. As Mr. Parker was in all probability (as he was when he left here for Cape Mount) an American citizen, and his surviving heirs are still in America I am in duty bound to intervene so far as to ask that you do not sell any of his effects unless there be such as may be classed as perishable goods, that will be spoiled before they can reach this Legation.

Neither are you authorized to settle his accounts by law but you will in the discharge of your duty as administrator of the effects of William Parker deceased, first take two other reputable persons with yourself making a committee of three reputable persons, who

who with yourself will take an accurate account of everything, including money, letters, books, and photos left by the deceased. You will make three copies of this inventory, each copy of which should be signed by all three of the committee.
You will retain one copy and send two copies signed by all three of the committee to me.
All his effects, including money, or money's value (a copy of which he filed in this legation before leaving for Cape Mount find enclosed).
You will cause to be boxed or locked up in trunks or other cases &c. transported to this legation.
You will also submit reasonable bills for necessary expenses, services rendered &c to this Legation with the effects of the deceased for settlement.

In case you find any letter or letters from the family or relatives of the deceased among his effects sufficient to give us a clue to the whereabouts of the family of the deceased you will be sure to forward the same to this legation.
Hoping an early reply I have the honor to ber yours in F. L. T. Owen L. W. Smith U.S. Min.R. and C. Gen.
Copy
Robertsport Territory G. C. Mount, December 6th, 12th, 1900.
To his Honorable Owen L. W. Smith, U.S. Minister, Liberia.

Dear Sir: Your of the 26th of November to hand and contents noticed, and in reply I beg to say that your letter was very much appreciated but at the same time, I had already submitted to what the judge of the Probate Court had ordered me to do. It was something new for me although I have served as administrator and appraiser in several estates but not of this kind. Brother William Parker arrived here 28th of September 1900 and died 14th Nov. 1900, he was speechless a while day and died without uttering

uttering a word. His key could not be found and we had to brake his trunk upon in order to get his cloths for to dress heirs. Two days after he was burried, we came across his keys in the mattress that he slept in, but having received further orders from you countermanding that of the Judge of the Probate Court, ordering me to send the things down to you, I therefore submit to you orders as United States Minister but before doing so I am hereby sending the bills from the estate desiring you to arrange some way for payment as the parties are crouding on me for their money or authorize me to settle the out of the effects. Also inform me how to get the things down to Monrovia as expenses will
will follow.
Awaiting an early reply, I am yours truly, Brother in F. L. & T. James H. Lewis, Sheriff Territory G.C. Mount.

The Estate of WIlliam Parker deceased to John W. Wagner Dr. For making one coffin . . . . $6.00 To Hayne Jordan and others digging grave $3.00 To carriers . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1.25 To Plank furnished for coffin. . . .2.48 ,, Nunse . . . . . . . . . . .2.00 ,, Six yds. shirting to binding coffin 1.20 ,, Two Appraisers appointed by Court 2.00 ,, Three ,, ,,,, yourself 3.00 ,, Clerk's Fee recording Inventory .75 ,, Administrator's Fees 9.00 ,, House rent for 12 days. . . . . 9.00 Total Amount $39.68
I am fixing up everything in order to forward them down to you as soon as I can get a reply from this letter.
I am fraternally yours in F. L. &T. James H. Lewis

P.S. I am very sorry to say that the amount of money that came to our hands did not tally with the list that you sent. Also some of the articles. But I will explain the matter in the next letter when I shall send the things down. Yours D. O.
Copy
No. 22/1900 Miscellaneous. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, Dec. 11. 1900.
James H. Lewis, Esq. Robertsport.
Sir: I have to acknowledge the receipt of your favor of Dec. 6, 1900, asking me for permission to settle certain accounts against the Estate of William Parker to the amount of $39.68.

In reply I have no authority in law to give you such power. I advised you according to law how to proceed and what to do with the effects of the deceased. To deviate from these rules will be the means of International disputes between the United States Government and the Liberian Government.

You must forward the effects with reasonable charges to this Legation for settlement &c. You must give the name of each person as well as the amount due each; stating for what the Estate due each person. I am to send a copy of your statment &c to the Secretary of the Treasury at Washington in my final settlement of the estate.
I have been informed that the lodge caused for and furnished brother Parker.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith, M. R. and C. General
